awd_titl_txt: Building Pathways for Hispanic Community College Students to Become STEM Teachers Through Mentoring and Experiential Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI) Program, this Track 2 project aims to make more undergraduate STEM students interested in pursuing careers in STEM teaching.  California's teacher shortage is acute in Southern California, where it has especially affected high-poverty, high-minority K-12 districts. These districts need many more, highly qualified STEM teachers with STEM degrees and teaching credentials, particularly in high schools.  These classrooms also face a widening gap between faculty and student demographics, which can affect student learning and success. This project will provide undergraduates with paid internships at an informal science institution, the Columbia Memorial Space Center.  Before and during their internship, the students will be mentored by college STEM faculty who have completed professional development to help them hone their mentoring skills.  These activities are designed to address two regional needs: 1) recruiting and retaining students from HSIs who are on track to achieve a STEM degree and a STEM secondary single-subject teaching credential; and 2) broadening participation in STEM teaching and the STEM workforce.  Teachers often report that they were drawn to the teaching profession by a positive teaching experience. Thus, this project intends to provide students with such an experience.  After training at the College, student interns will have teaching experiences that include facilitating field trips and other learning experiences at the Columbia Memorial Space Center.  Because at least 70% of the students at the college are Hispanic, most students participating in the internship will also be Hispanic.  The expected project deliverables include outreach to at least 3,000 K-12 students, paid internships for up to 60 undergraduate interns, and improved mentoring skills in participating faculty.

The project research plan is designed to advance understanding of the effectiveness of paid internships in informal STEM education settings to attract students (particularly Hispanic students) into secondary-STEM teaching professions. The project will address three research questions: 1) To what extent do the different elements of the project (recruitment, mentors, internship, etc.) contribute to community college students’ pursuit of STEM degrees and students’ perception of secondary school teaching as a viable STEM-related career? 2) In what ways does the project contribute to the development of students’ identity as both a STEM learner and STEM teacher? 3) To what extent do students’ experiences as informal science educators during the internship support the development of effective practices for science teaching and communication? The project will use a mixed methods approach, employing research tools that include focus groups, surveys, academic records, and validated research instruments. By the end of its three-year funding period, the program expects to achieve a 30% (18 student) increase in the College’s secondary teacher preparation pathway and that these students will be both pursuing STEM degrees and intending to receive a single-subject teaching credential in a STEM discipline.  The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The BE-STELLAR (Building Eventual STEM-Secondary Teachers’ Experiential Learning and Relevance) program, funded by NSF, aimed to support Hispanic community college students in sustaining their interest in STEM careers while introducing and encouraging science teaching as a potential career pathway. The program included two core components: (1) a 26-week internship at the Columbia Memorial Space Center and (2) ongoing mentoring sessions with science faculty from Cerritos College. The project was conducted between Summer 2020 and Spring 2022, engaging 47 students in total.  A no cost extension was granted, allowing an additional 8 students to participate Fall 2023 through Spring 2024.

Key Outcomes

The outcomes of the BE-STELLAR project can be categorized into several themes: professional skill development, academic and career support, identity formation, and interest in STEM education.

1. Professional and Academic Skill Development

Internship and mentoring activities significantly contributed to students' professional growth and confidence in STEM. Specific outcomes included:

  • Communication and People Skills:
    Participants reported improved public speaking skills, confidence in explaining scientific concepts, and the ability to engage diverse audiences effectively. They also developed crowd management and interpersonal skills, crucial for both STEM careers and teaching​.
  • Soft Skills Enhancement:
    Students strengthened essential soft skills such as time management, goal setting, organization, resume writing, and stress management, all of which are beneficial for academic and career success​.
  • STEM Knowledge Growth:
    Interns gained hands-on experience with STEM concepts, real-world applications, and informal science education while working at the Columbia Memorial Space Center. They also connected theoretical STEM knowledge with practical applications, reinforcing their academic pursuits​.

2. Career and Academic Support

The mentorship program and networking opportunities played a pivotal role in guiding students toward STEM careers. Outcomes included:

  • Career Path Reflection & Development:
    Students gained clarity on their career interests through mentorship and exposure to STEM professionals. Some solidified their STEM career choices, while others explored alternative career paths, including science teaching​.
  • Networking and Professional Connections:
    Through their internships and mentoring, participants built relationships with peers, faculty, and STEM professionals, which increased their awareness of career opportunities and resources​.
  • Access to Educational and Career Resources:
    Students learned about internships, scholarships, workshops, and professional development opportunities, which helped them navigate college and plan for future careers​

3. Identity Formation and STEM Career Interest

A key goal of the BE-STELLAR program was to foster students’ STEM identity and interest in STEM-related careers, including teaching. Notable findings include:

  • Sustained or Increased Interest in STEM Careers:
    A majority of students maintained or strengthened their motivation to pursue STEM careers throughout the program. Survey data indicated that interest in careers such as scientist (83% to 92%) and engineer (70% to 76%) increased slightly​.
  • Introduction to Science Teaching as a Career:
    The program successfully encouraged students to consider science teaching as a viable career path. Interest in teaching careers rose from 57% to 73% over the program duration​.
  • Identity as STEM Professionals:
    Students began to see themselves as part of the broader STEM community. Through participation in mentorship, networking, and hands-on experiences, students gained a sense of belonging and confidence in their STEM identities​.

4. Perceptions of Science Education and Teaching

Another major outcome was the shift in students' perceptions of teaching as a STEM career:

  • Exposure to Teaching Practices:
    Participants developed skills in conveying scientific information, adapting to diverse learners, and creating engaging, hands-on learning experiences. They gained insights into how teaching can be an extension of their STEM expertise​.
  • Reconsideration of Teaching as a Career Path:
    Many participants gained respect for educators and considered teaching as a possible future career, even if they had not initially planned to pursue education​.

 

Conclusion

The BE-STELLAR program successfully provided academic, professional, and personal support to students, helping them navigate STEM education and career paths. By combining mentorship, hands-on STEM experiences, and exposure to science communication and teaching, the program reinforced students' commitment to STEM careers while introducing them to teaching as a valuable and fulfilling profession.
